modeFinder 1.0.2
  • Reference

Compute the univariate empirical mode via Bernstein polynomials.

Source: R/RcppExports.R
emp_mode.Rd

Compute the empirical mode estimate based on Bernstein polynomials density function with automated mechanism of choosing appropriate degree of Bernstein polynomials.

Based on the smooth options, this R function returns either simple empirical mode estimate, kenerl density mode estimate or Bernstein polynomials based mode estimate (default).

emp_mode(data, fix_lower = NULL, fix_upper = NULL, smooth = TRUE,
  smooth_option = "Bernstein", smooth_density = FALSE,
  density_points = 512L, m_degree = NULL, sample_size = 1000L,
  m_knots = NULL)

Arguments

data

An univariate sample data.
fix_lower

A lower bound of the support; If NULL (default), set min0, the minimum of the sample data; Set a particualr value otherwise.
fix_upper

An upper bound of the support; If NULL (default), set max1, the maximum of the sample data; Set a particualr value otherwise.
smooth

An indicator of if performing Bernstein polynomials smoothing or not; If TRUE (default), adopt Bernstein polynomials density function; If FALSE, adopt empirical density function without smoothing.
smooth_option

If smooth = TRUE, an option of smoothing method for empirical density function; "Bernstein" (default) indicates Bernstein polynomials density estimate, and "kernel" the kernel density estimate.
smooth_density

If smooth = TRUE, an indicator of if output the density function or not; If FALSE (default), only the mode estimate is given; If TRUE, the smooth density function is also included in the output.
density_points

If smooth = TRUE, a number of equally spaced points for the output density function or not, default is 512.
m_degree

If smooth = TRUE and smooth_option = "Bernstein", a degree of Bernstein polynomials; If NA (default), pick the one with maximal p-value until exceeding 0.95; Set a particualr value otherwise.
sample_size

If smooth = TRUE and smooth_option = "Bernstein", a subsample size used for Anderson-Darling criterion, and default is 1e+03.
m_knots

If smooth = TRUE and smooth_option = "kernel", a number of knots in finding the maximum of empirical density function; If NA (default), set m_knots = sample size of data; Set a particualr value otherwise.

Value

An empirical mode of data, a degree of Bernstein polynomials adopted with the maximum p-value and the corresponding maximum p-value of the Anderson-Darling criterion based on the subsample and Bernstein polynomials; NA if not applicable.

Examples

n = 1e6
set.seed(1)
data = rbeta(n, 2, 5)
## Return Bernstein polynomials based mode estimate
emp_mode(data)
#> The mode estimate is choosen as the maximum point of Bernstein polynomials density estimate.
#> $mode
#> [1] 0.2007149
#> 
#> $`optimal alpha`
#> [1] 0.35
#> 
#> $`optimal p-value`
#> [1] 0.9963385
#> 
## Return kenerl density mode estimate
emp_mode(data, smooth_option = "kernel")
#> $mode
#> [1] 0.2043386
#> 
## Return simple empirical mode estimate
emp_mode(data, smooth = FALSE)
#> The mode estimate is choosen as the mid point of interval with maximum difference among knots equally-spaced intervals.
#> $`number of knots`
#> [1] 1000000
#> 
#> $mode
#> [1] 0.2081525
#>
